docs.lead_paragraph: No one shifted an armchair, moved a flower arrangement or asked an unexpected question. President Obama gave five back-to-back television interviews broadcast on Sunday that were as tightly choreographed -- and eerily similar -- as the multiple Magritte bowler-hatted men milling in the remake of ''The Thomas Crown Affair.''

headline.main: For President, Five Programs, One Message

docs.snippet: The president’s talk-show grand slam was a remarkable  and remarkably overt  display of media management.

multimedia.credit: President Obama's appearance on NBC's 'Meet the Press' was one of five television interviews he used on Sunday to promote his health care agenda.
multimedia.caption: Obama on 'Meet the Press'

docs.lead_paragraph: A reader's comment in the Prescriptions column on Thursday in reaction to the health care proposal introduced by Senator Max Baucus misstated the maximum penalty a family might face under the plan for not having insurance coverage. As an accompanying article reported, the highest possible penalty would be $3,800 a year, not $1,500.
docs.abstract: Correction of Sept 17 article on health care proposal by Sen Max Baucus, regarding penalties for not having insurance coverage
docs.snippet: A reader's comment in the Prescriptions column on Thursday  in reaction to the health care proposal introduced by Senator Max Baucus misstated the maximum penalty a family might face under the plan for not having insurance coverage. As an...

docs.lead_paragraph: Although cast as a tax on gold-plated insurance policies for the well-heeled, it has prompted anxiety among the middle class. The idea, proposed last Wednesday by Senator Max Baucus, is to help raise money for the nation's health care overhaul by placing a new excise tax on the most expensive health insurance policies, like the ones offered to partners at Goldman Sachs and other affluent professionals.

headline.main: A Proposed Tax on the Cadillac Health Insurance Plans May Also Hit the Chevys

docs.abstract: Middle class Americans are expressing misgivings about proposal by Sen Max Baucus to impose excise tax on most expensive health insurance policies to help raise funds for health care overhaul; so-called Cadillac insurance policies could include ones that cover many middle-income Americans if insurance premiums continue to rise faster than inflation; graph; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A proposed tax on expensive insurance policies to help raise money for the nation’s health care overhaul could also affect modest plans.

byline.original: By REED ABELSON; Geraldine Fabrikant contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: International U.S. FEARS THAT MORE AID
docs.snippet: International     U.S. FEARS THAT MORE AID

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama was seen, heard and rehashed all day. Indeed, Sunday was more of a marathon for the reporters and pundits scrambling to weigh in on Mr. Obama's five television appearances than for the president, who rounded off the day with an unusual 18-hole golf game (more than four and a half hours for those of you keeping track).

docs.lead_paragraph: It's a newsy morning for New York after the revelation that the White House is trying to steer the state governor away from the 2010 gubernatorial race and the news of three arrests in the terrorism case that included an F.B.I. raid of at least two Queens apartments.
docs.abstract: It's a newsy morning for New York City after the revelation that the White House is trying to boot New York's governor from the 2010 gubernatorial race and an arrest in the terrorism case that began last week with an F.B.I. raid of at least two Queens apartments.
